reviews.review_text: It's difficult to follow up a classic. It always feels like something is lost when a great game from years ago is brought into the modern age. Things get prettier, bigger, and more streamlined, but many times it feels like some essential chemistry is lost. Some of us blame nostalgia, others simply write the developers off as appealing to the largest audience or the lowest common denominator. Sequels always lose something.  Which is why Triumph Studios had no right to produce such a perfect game.  This is the perfect sparkling bouquet of what made the original great, combined with the streamlined production quality we've come to expect from a quality modern game. It's asymmetrical and unfair in the most balanced ways possible. Whether you're outfitting your heroes or designing your player class, you'll find great satisfaction in trying to break the game. You'll be very good at some things, and very bad at others, but it will always make sense and it will always feel right.  The unit design deserves special mention. Each unit is deeply well-crafted and unique, even when comparing racial units of the same role. The attention to synergy is unmatched, both between units of the same race and in the way that race and class combine to make a whole. Leveling up often provides interesting new abilities that also tend to synergize, instead of simply providing better stats.  This game has a lot of everything, and all of it affects everything else. You'll build cities, research and cast spells, and train units. You'll command armies on the beautiful strategic map, and when you explore dungeons or fight another army, you'll go down to fight on equally beautiful tilesets. Tactical combat is reasonably simple but very deep. This game has not been casualized. The A.I. is maddeningly clever, and you won't take this statement seriously until you've experienced it. You'll fight skirmishes in the woods with bandits, and you'll fight in truly massive sieges to conquer cities. Your heroes will explore dungeons, find and equip items, and lead your armies into battle.  You will build your strategy, and then get excited about other strategies you think could work. They probably will. Your race, your class, and your specializations all fundamentally change the way you need to approach the game. It takes a long time to bloom into a full understanding of how the various parts of the game work together, but the journey is pleasant, and you can absorb it by playing.  The campaign probably deserves it's own review. It's gloriously cheesy golden-age high fantasy. The campaign follows branching questlines, so you can end up doing different missions. The base game has two campaigns of eight missions. Eight does not sound like a lot but you can easily spend an entire day playing one mission. They're huge. Think of them more like chapters. The expansion packs can add another two campaigns.   There are also a number of scenarios which are like competitive missions for X players. The 'real' Age of Wonders though is in the procedurally generated random map mode, where you can fight other players or the AI. There are a huge number of random features on the maps, such as 'dwellings' where you can purchase units from a non-player faction like Giants or Pixies. You'll need to play many games before you've seen everything you can find. Also of note, Age of Wonders has an underground map, full of caves, tunnels, and the cities of the Goblins and Dwarves.  Triumph is confident enough in the mastery of their game to give the player enormous freedoms to explore how to play. Their own mastery is evident in the careful design of how every element acts together. If you find anything this game does interesting, play it for that reason, but be prepared to fall in love with the rest.   This is what a strategy game should be.   10/10

Disclaimers :  - I was a closed beta tester for the base game as well as its two expansions. However I'm not an employee of Triumph Studios, only a community volunteer.  - This review was written post Eternal Lords and 1.5 patch releases.    Age of Wonders III is a turn based hex based fantasy 4x game that is a lot more combat focused compared to something like the Civilization series but also quite a bit more strategically and tactically involved than let's say Heroes of Might & Magic which can be both good or bad depending on your personal preferences.     Gameplay   Compared to the previous games AoWIII retains most of the series' fundamentals but also iterates and adds to the formula.   The most notable change is the way yor faction is presented via the class system. Your research tree and unit roster are not only determined by spell school and starting race picks but by your leader class (warlords, sorcerer, archdruid, dreadnaught, etc.), starting race as well as specializations which are akin to the previous game's spell spheres and leader skills. Your base unit list is thus determined by the race of the towns you own as well as your chosen class.  Comparing it to AoWII the class system in a way separates the racial aspect of a faction from the   gameplay theme  of it. For example, in AoW2 Elves were always Druids with nature themed units, Archons were always Theocrats with their religious and holy theme, Dwarves were Dreadnoughts due to their technological prowes, Orcs were Warlords with strong physical combatants and so on.   The AoWIII class system separates race and theme so Elves can be steampunk-ish technologists, Dwarves can wield druidic powers while Goblins can be religious crusaders. Thematically this allows you to create both stereotypical combinations (wizard elves) as well as some unusual ones (holy angelic goblins).   Gameplay wise the trio of race, class and specialization (additional mini tech trees) allows for a myriad of different play styles and strategies and a very diverse meta game which encourages experimentation and greately enhances replayability.   Each class comes with a unique tech tree which consists of special class units which can have their own racial variations as well as a large number of combat or strategic spells and passive upgrades that enhance your empire as well as units.    Customization   AoWIII features a leader creation process which allows for detailed aesthetic and gameplay customization. Visual options are akin to rpg games like Dragon Age allowing for changes to race, gender, clothing, accessories, hair style and color, skin color, eyes, hats masks, postures, background scenery, portrait poses, coat of arms, etc.  Gameplay-wise the options include race, class and 3 slots for specializations that can be magic oriented or more mundane empire upgrades.  Game settings include numerous tweaks to the random map generator like map type (land, continents, islands), map size (s, m, l, xl), geographical settings (types of terrain and climate, existence of the underground layer), starting town/army, amount of resources, treasure sites, independent monsters, etc.   Furthermore various game parameters can be tweaked like the number of heroes, hero level cap, hero race, game pace, starting resources, turn progression (classic i-go-you-go or simultanious), empire quests, map events, victory conditions, type and number of opponents, preference for manual or auto-combat and so on.  Much effort was made to cater to different preferences and play styles.    Combat   Like in Heroes of Might & Magic for example, combat in AoWIII happens on a separate tactical map that is derived from the participating units' position on the strategic map. If the units were standing on a snowy arctic hex the tactical map will also have snow on it for example. Same with forests, swamps, etc. Not only that but various sites like cities, farms, dungeons, mines, tombs, etc. are all represented on the tactical map and can have different effects like providing obstacles, choke points, magical effects and so on.  Compared to AoWII combat in AoWIII has less randomness and is more dependent on the player making the right moves. Attacks will always hit for example (except under special circumstances) but the damage can still vary and there is the possibility of criticals or fumbles.  There are many things to keep an eye on in combat like move points (usually the less you have the less attacks you get but not always), limited retaliations, defensive stances, attacks of opportunity, flanking attacks, distances, unit position and facing, range, the presence of obstacles or city walls, types of movement (walking, floating, flying) and so on.  And this is without taking into account unit stats (physical attack vs. defence, magical/elemental attack vs. resistance), traits, special abilities, morale (which influences critical chance), combat spells, unit and battlefield enchantments, unit types, etc.  The basics of combat are simple. Click on a unit, right click to attack an enemy unit. But is the enemy unit far enough to trigger the charge ability, can I flank it, what's the chance of my special effect triggering, what elemental protections does it have, how many retaliations does it have remaining, does it have first strike, is it a polearm unit and will my cavalry take extra damage, can I weaken it prior to attack and how, can I kill it, will my unit survive the next turn after it attacks...there are many questions you could end up asking yourself.  Learning about the units, what abilities they have and how they can be used and combined for maximum effectiveness is necessary for mastering the game but learning can be achieved in gradual steps.  AoWIII retains the adjacency rule of previous games so all armies that are adjacent to the hex being attacked will also participate in combat which can result in some pretty large battles. Thankfully animation speed in battle can be adjusted during combat.   Units and heroes that perform well and survive will accumulate experience points and become stronger acquiring new abilities as they level up and grow into valued veterans.     Strategy   On the strategic level you build up your empire by settling or capturing new cities and expanding your borders in order to bring more and more resources under your control. There are resource sites to be captured, treasure sites to be explored, artifacts to be found, neutral creatures, cities and enemy leaders to be subdued. All in all the world is a dangerous place and venturing forth requires combat worthy armies and leaders. Luckily there is a beautiful cloth map to be zoomed out to in order to get an overview of the situation.  Resource gathering and exploration primarily serve the goal of building up armies that can defeat the dangers that lie beyond your borders.   A new addition here compared to AoWII are the creature dwellings which function as minor races that offer unique units for hire as well as their own sets of buildings. These dwellings can expand your unit roster and provide unexpected tactical and strategic options.  Both creature dwellings and independent cities can be outright conqured or negotiated with towards peaceful annexation by vooing them with money or performing quests. How you treat various towns and races can determine their attitude towards you as well as your alignment and diplomatic relations.   Another addition is that clearing out and controlling certain treasure sites can unlock special unit or town upgrades in cities controlling those sites which can make some cities more valuable than others.   All in all after 618 hrs of playing I have not yet experienced everything this game has to offer, so many untried combinations and strategies, which is probably the biggest endorsement I can give.

Imagine Civ 5, but with combat that actually felt fun to do, choices that were actually meaningful and the ability to create and flesh out your own leader of one of numerous races. The gameplay is less than stagnant, it has mob support and it's campaign is awesome.

This hidden gem game I found only this December. As a big fan of old HOMAM and CIV games I cannot describe how amazed I am by this game... Its like my childhood dream comes true! I will recommend this game to everybody, already give it to my brother for Christmas, he loves it too.

It's a true spiritual successor to Master of Magic and that's what I love about it  I would estimate that I played somewhere in the vicinity of 1000 hours on the original Master of Magic (in fact, still have it and play it occasionally on Dosbox). It had been a pinnacle of fantasy TBS games, unsurpassed by any, in my opinion.   until this game came along.   To any MoM player, Age of Wonders III will feel right at home. From mage customization to the exploration of ruins and caves, the settling of new cities and the building of great armies, the researching of grand spells to strike your opponents and bless your lands... and of course the heroes - numerous and varied.   The races are fairly unique, with no two feeling alike. Playing anything from Elves to Pantherfolk, the difference between units and cities are big enough to merit playing at least once with each race. Add to that the different classes and magic skills you can customize your leader with and you get near infinite replayability   The music is great - I found myself walking around humming some of the battle tunes plenty of times... the visuals are fairly good for a TBS and I doubt anyone would complain much about them...   The multiplayer returns the classic old Hotseat option, which definitely feels good for an old-timer like me...  So far I've played well over 200 hours and I am still playing... it's just great.

This is a really fun game. I like the tactical battles for this game. I have quite a few turn based fantasy 4x games, and the tactical battles for AoW have always been fun. There are lots of unit types. Also, players get to cast many spells while playing the game, both tactical and stratgic. Leader customization is great, and starting new scenarios is neat due to all of the choices availble.   AoW III is also a very pretty game. The graphics and sound are phenomenal. There are spells that allow the player to change the terrain. Tactical maps also look good, with a lot of environment colors.  Overall AoW III is a good, fun game.

Really solid 4X with extremely in-depth combat and plent of units, spells, etc. to play with to make your perfect army. The developers have show a huge amount of support for the game and have gone out of the way to listen to criticisms to iron out the flaws that stuck out on release. I definetly would recommend this to anyone who enjoys the 4X genre just for the combat alone.  Note: This isn't fantasy Civ 5; The game focuses more on the war aspect of 4X's than it does the empire/economy management, so if your strictly looking for a game with that Civ feeling then you might want to watch some youtube videos to get an idea if this is a game for you.

EDIT 23-11-2016 - This game still stands the test of time, if you still haven't bought it; Do it now!  EDIT 17-04-2015 - With the new Eternal Lords expansion in combination with the free 1.5 patch, this game is even better than it was originally.    Twelve years we waited for the successor of the excellent Shadow Magic (also available on Steam). And is it worth it? Hell yes!  The graphics, soundtrack and (re)playability are excellent!   As the Devs are a small company from Holland, and independent publishers, they actively browse and reply on the official forums, making notes of bugs (although there are very few bugs at release) and planning on fixing them in future patches. The same is regarding balancing issues. They are very actively gathering balancing suggestions and also implementing them thorugh patches. They are very close to the community and that is something most software companies can learn from. Regular patches are already released and more are in the pipeline.  The game itself comes with an editor, so you can make your own maps/campaigns. Furthermore single-player options are two campaigns, about 8 scenarios and, the icing on the cake, a Random Map Generator. This generator makes very good maps with realistic landmasses. Maps can be selected for small to extra large size and 2-8 players. There is also a multiplayer mode which supports Hotseat (players take turns on the same computer), LAN (need to make contact with official servers first, after that it's offline), VPN (in beta patch at the time of writing) and normal multiplayer games through the internet.  I already netted 165 hours in the game, which was released just 16 days ago (at the time of writing) and I just cannot stop playing! This game is highly recommended, not only for gameplay purposes, but also to support the independent developer!

So, i nominated this game for some Steam Award and now i have to write a review for 25XP. Deal with it! Still, i'm going to write a full review as someone wo has nearly 400 hours in Age of Wonder 2: Shadowmagic, and... well, a lot less hours in Civ 5.  So what is Age of Wonders 3? Age of Wonders 3 is a turn based Strategy game strongly focused around combat, in a pretty standard fanatasy setting. You have elfs, orcs, goblins, halflings and some more unique races like fronstlings and draconians for example. You play as a highly customizable wizard, learning spells and taking over cities, you can upgrade to build stronger and more units, either by producing them in the cities or summoning them with magic. You have multiple classes for your wizard, that kind of work based on the rock paper scissors principle. You'll be able to recruit heros, who can cast some spells as well, and whom you can level up and equip, just like your wizard. Unlike in the previous Age of Wonders game you have the option for your heroes, that if they die in battle, they'll still life on afterwards, unless you lose the bettle entirely. But then you can just resurrect them, using a spell, everyone gets sooner or later. This makes things much less frustrating for those who wish so.  The other big new thing in AoW3 is flanking. In AoW2 you could come in with a few string units and just ♥♥♥♥ up a whole army of individualy weaker units with ease, unless you enemie had a big defensive advantage. Flanking gives you new tactical method to make your numbers count, if used well, and it makes some stealthy units more viable, by focusing their skills on this tool, not just having invisibility or concealment on the worldmap.  Yes, there is a worldmap and a 'new' map for each battle. Playing CIV5 after AoW is the least satisfying thing in regards of combat ever. It's like playing ludo after falling in love with chess. You can fire with archers or priests from the top of your city wall, while the enemie sends massive wallbreakers to tear down your gates. Meanwhile his flying unity just pass the wall, trying to take out your raged units. As your last archer dies you cast a massive firestorm for lots of damage on every unit on the battlefield, including your own ones. This is combat.  Now there are some cons i'll have to point out. First of all i am not a fan of the campain. As much as i'd like to play it, the missions are just annoying to me. I can't really explayin why, sorry. But i've never liked the campain in any AoW game, while there are many others who loved them. So most of the time i'm just playing randoms maps. The second thing i'd like to point out is a point that occurs in every round i'm playing. It's the point where you are (if you're winning) reaching superiority in a game it becomes boring. They implemented the option for leaders to surrender to you, which i really appreciate, but if you play a 4-player match and took over the cities of 2 of them already, the last enemie is pretty boring to defeat most of the times. That's why i rarely ever finish a game. The third thing are the difficulty settings for the AI. The AI cheats on higher difficulties. They get way more resources, combat bonuses agains independent units, like for example a group of dwarfs protecting a mine, and other stuff. That's not a good way to create difficulty in my opinion. And at last the DLC problem. No, i think the pricing is ok, but i also think they are mandatory for a good experience. The base game just feeld a bit empty.  But now a quick sum up of all the great stuff, and belive me, there is a lot! The combat is great, and if your Army of Angels has to fight a pack of wolves you can just let the battle fight out automatically. The new class-system is a welcoming difference. The environment looks gorgeous, even on (most) random generated maps. I still prefer the soundtrack of AoW2 but it's still great in AoW3. Never had any problems with online play. The spells are great. The customization options for the leaders give a lot of variety and a lot of different options for tactics.  To sum it up. Age of Wonders 3 is a great turn based game that lacks the economical complexity of games like Civ, but provides a superior tactical combat experience in a good looking fantasy setting.  8,9/10 because i can play as a goblin druid and it's great!
An actually good remake of Master of Magic. If you enjoyed AoW2 or MoM this is the game for you! Fantastic and worth every penny.

I was a big fan of Age of Wonders II and Age of Wonders II: Shadow Magic so it is natural like I would like AoW III. This turn-based strategy game with a fantasy theme is sort of a mix between Heroes of Might & Magic and Civilization. At least for me, I like AoW best of all. I love the hero units in this game and the way they level, have items/mounts, and can use spells. I love that there is incentive to level and grow even the normal units as their stats get better and they may get additional abilities at higher levels. I love being able to choose what each city is producing whether it be units or some building that will give that city an ability or boost. AoW III does not have the race and unit variety that AoW II: Shadows Magic had but they keep adding races and whatnot via expansions so maybe it will get there eventually.  I like the single-player campaigns thus far but there are some things that bother me. First, sometimes the missions force you to be very aggressive in order to win. If you are too slow then the AI can wipe you out or at least make the mission drag out way longer than it should take. Second, I love to focus on leveling my heroes and the campaign missions usually have a hero level cap that gets higher as you get deeper into a campaign. I understand the reasoning for that but my interest drops when I can't grow my heroes anymore. The best part about the campaigns is that you get to keep your heroes mission to mission. All their XP and items and skill points remain. There is a caveat though but I'm not sure how much I should say about it since it could be a story spoiler.  I have about 80 hours played thus far and I haven't even finished the first out of four single-player campaigns (I think the base game comes with 2 campaigns and the expansions add more). I am definitely getting my money's worth. Even if/when I finish all the campaigns I can easily create scenarios against AIs or players where I control the map size and whatnot (a la Civilization). That is what I often did on AoW II.  This is not a game I will play all the time but I will always come back to it periodically where I get all excited about it once again and sink a lot of time into it for at least a couple weeks.
It's like a mix of Age of Empires + Civ + XCom. I love it. Definitely recemmend it.
Love the game. Definitely feels like the original AOW1. If you like AOW, you'll love this game.

I wish I knew about this game sooner. It incorporates features from Civilization, Total War, and XCOM in a turn-based format.  ========================================= Pros:  I'm just playing single-player so far, but I'm loving the RPG elements of leveling your leader and troops.  You can research spells which you can use to cast spells in combat (buffing troops, damaging enemies, etc), or cast spells outside of combat (damaging enemy armies, buffing your cities, etc.)  Sieges are well done as far as giving the defender a big advantage, but still making siege weapons useful. Not enough games use these mechanics properly.  Each race has it's own pros and cons, and each leader has their own spells and stats, some of which you can influence when they level up. There is a custom leader creator as well which is pretty cool.  Great value. Got this game on a -66% Steam sale, absolutely worth the price. Only bought the base game, but in the first hour realized I would enjoy it enough to buy the whole package.  ============================================= Cons  There is a lot of micro-management, but it's turn-based and similar to Civilization. So if Civ was overwhelming, this may not be the game for you.  Battles can be a little tedious because you move and attack with every unit. Also most units have their own spells and ranks, so it's not too horrible. I'm not disliking combat yet, but I can see where some might. There is an auto-resolve option like Total War though.  Edit for multiplayer review; highly not recommended. You have to watch every battle as other players complete their battles. There is auto-resolve, but this game is all about tactical battles and it's unplayable like that. However, there is play-by-email and that works fine, so if you don't mind doing that, then it's do-able. Really disappointing, but it's because of gameplay balance.   =================================================  All in all, if you enjoy Civilization, XCOM, or Total War, then you would probably enjoy this game.    Also, that guy who has 100 hours played and still didn't recommend this game, stop being so entitled. That's a great value.

I miss the variety provided by its predecessor in terms of races and great changes of units from one race to the next. That being said, this game adds its own type of variety with the leader classes, and the game provides a very solid turn based gameplay. The combat is involved, and your leader is an active participant in your conquest. In alot of ways, this game is more akin to a sequel of Age of Wonders 1, than it is a sequel to the more widely popular, AoW: SM.   Fun, engaging, and as always, it has the hated feeling of 'one more turn is all I need'.
This is a damm good game. I've enjoy playing this game a lot. It is better than the oiginal and the soundtrack is awesome.
Best 4x fantasy strategy game ever.    Great combat mechanics    Awesome character customization    Exploration is fun
A fine update of the AoW series. It is essentially AoW 2 for the modern era. Well designed, good graphics for this type of game, and very fun. I highly recommend if you enjoy strategy or 4x games.

I've played a variety of 4X games and I can say, undoubdelty, this is the ONE for me.  I like Civ, don't get me wrong, Civ is a pretty amazing game, but it was way too focused on nation interrelations, diplomacy and 'player versus player' experience, as in, you'll be battling and dealing with the big AI (the other players in the game) rather than the environment AI (in the case of civ, barbarians)  I also played Fallen Enchantress, but the art didn't quite charm me.  This game combines what I loved from FE (exploration, variety of AI enemies, more 'player versus environment' focused) with an incredibly beautiful artstyle, amazing soundtrack and a much more fleshed out singleplayer campaign. Highly recommended for any fan of strategy games, be it 4X, grand or tactics.

When I was young I played the original Age of Wonders to death. As i got older I still played it and it became one of my most beloved games. Now while I do have a biased point of view I will tell you this : AOW3 Feels so much like the original is frightening. It seems like Triumph decided to start with the original and flesh out what was good and shave off the bad. I feel that they did a fantastic job making this game exactly what it should be.   The overall gameplay makes you think that its a CIV knockoff but after playig it for some time I realized that its just similar, nothing more. I like the overall feel of the game and the only complaint I had was that the screen scrolling seemed quite clunky.  I truly think they did a great job making the combat system emulate the original while giving it a unique feel that makes you want more. I'm excited that they kept commander (or leaders) in the game which nearly makes the game a turn based RPG. One of the best additions to this sequel is the ability to create a random map. While random maps are pretty standard now (or should be honestly) it brings a breath of longevity to the game.  If you enjoy turn based stragety games that are fun and have dynamic combat this is the game for you. I truly think you'll spend hours enjoying this game and exploring or conquering your own world!
4 HOURS INTO THIS SHEET AND LOVED IT. NO REVIEW NEEDED. GOOD GAME!

This game is brilliant. If you're looking for a fantasy 4x with a military/tactics focus, this game takes the cake. Economy management is extremely simple compared to Civ5 or other 4x games so if that's your interest I'd look elsewhere. However the unit diversity, spells, and tactical battles of this game are unmatched.   The assymetrical balance via combinations of starting race and leader class really makes for truly epic dynamic compared to the copy pasted civilizations featured in other games. Playing a Dreadnaught (engineer) leader is a whole different ball game from playing a Druid or a Theurgist. Seeing a battlefield of up to 42 units strewn with one army of cannons, tanks, and musket men standing on a city wall vs an army of shaman and summoned beasts set to a wonderful backdrop of a massive rising city scape really brings the game to life.  Worth every penny.
Think Civ + HoMM. Really liking it thus far!

Considering the good/bad comments about AOW, there is not much left to say apart from:  PRO:  -This game is a total BLAST in Multiplayer - even in hotseat mode when everybody is watching your moves (paranoia reigns !) - People complaining about the lack of depth (economy): Name a *good* (like CIV4 or Endless Space) game where the economical micromanagement was'nt just a time consuming boredom-factor once you got past the number crunching.. - AOW3 IS heavily combat-focused - and in that discipline it shines on every level. The amount of tactical decisions to be made (terrain, movement, stats, buffs, debuffs, resistances etc.) combined with clever army builing is JUST RIGHT to let this game FLOW. In this regard, AOW3 succeeds where all the other titles (HoMM 4-6, Disciples, Fallen Enchantress) have failed miserably.  CONTRA: - The Number 1 Mistake of new Players (and obviously the reason for a lot of bad tempered 'reviews') is the misinterpretation of the way the units are represented (HP/DMG-wise). FOLKS ! The Number of 3d-Models in a Unit is JUST A REPRESENTATION of the Hitpoints - where low-tier units have i.e. 5 figures and high-tier units just one model..so: no, once the Orc Shock Trooper slot looses a model (HP) it does not inflict less damage. It's all a matter of interpretation. My real Contra with this is that the devs did not consider the necessity of explaining this is in some sort of tutorial. It's 2014 and the kids are used to playing stupid crap where everything is chewed for them...what a good 4x game does is leaving some room for imagination, only visualizing what is necessary to establish the mood. But it's a sad fact that , in order to sell these concepts to the masses - you have to *educate* them a little bit - Diplomacy. Just plain boring. What i'm really missing is an AI that displays total irrational reactions (a goblin druid declaring war on you just because you captured his favoured neutral tavern; an allied dwarven theocrat who is a racist ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and breaks the alliance because you have chosen not to migrate the last town you captured to your heroes race...you got the idea. Where everything else in TBS is about numbers and logic - diplomacy should be about lying, cheating, egos and taste - just like real world politics :) - The random Map Generator needs serious tweaking. There is some sort of 'Mountain Spaming' on large map types with 'underground' and even player numbers...very annoying.  Bottom Line:  There is always a lot of work to be done. Some Unit-Stats tweaking here, some AI-Polishing there. Regarding the overall game design, AOW3 does it right. There have been lots of discussions about the typical TBS issues: Balancing the time exposure / gameflow ratio; how to avoid the stack of doom, complexity vs. laid back indulgence. The fundamentals are here, they play very well and boy - do they look good. With some more effort, this will be the best fantasy-themed TBS-Game since the days of MoM...
Amazing game with endless replayability. If you like Civilization V, you will love Age of Wonders III!

I haven't played Endless legend, but both of these games seemed similar and I had the choice between them.  After some research: the basic difference is probably that Endless Legend is closer to Civilization/ Warlock, and Age of wonders is closer to Heroes of Might and magic. The basics of it are you build an army, learn new spells, and march your gathered army to victory. On the main map, you can cast spells to help you and your allies or hinder your foes. You can explore the map for powerful items to equip your leader and heroes with. When you fight another army you switch to a tactical battle mode. Grading Scale: 10 - Masterpiece 9 - Amazing 8 - Great 7 - Good 6 - Okay 5 - Mediocre 4 - Bad 3 - Terrible 2 - Abomination 1 - Unplayable  Game: Age of Wonders III  Summary: Turn-based strategy game with some RPG elements and a fantasy setting.  Pros:  Combat- Refreshing and fun for a turn based strategy game. Although some flaws are evident (will go over it in the 'cons' section). Combat takes place in a battlefield that takes into account the type of terrain you were on when combat was initiated. You can move your units around and place them in strategic areas around the field.  Character Customization- Able to customize your hero with different hairstyles and certain cosmetic options such as armor and head pieces.   RPG Elements- Able to equip your hero with items that are obtained throughout the world. You can also level your hero and have him/her learn new spells and moves. Among these units are mounts which really give your hero a unique feel.  Units- Each unit is unique and inspired. Although you cannot customize your units the same way you can your hero, they each have their own unique abilities and appearance.   Cons:  Limited Victories: Although diplomacy is possible, the style of the game begs for a conquest win. The resources at your disposal for any other type of victories are simply not worth the effort. It's a lot of fun to just stomp through everything with your unique armies.  Repetitiveness- After playing for a while. Combat can get a bit tedious to a point where you just find yourself skipping it altogether. Once that happens, the rest of the game just doesn't hold up. Combat is the fun part of this game, not so much the diplomacy.    Verdict: Fun turn-based strategy game with a fun twist on combat that suffers from repetitiveness. In this game, the main premise is a large scale rivalry between powerful mages with varying specializations and studies, who bend cities by their will toward good, evil, or whatever.  Gameplay is reminiscent mostly of Heroes of Might and Magic, in a good way. This is a 4X game with an especially strong emphasis on exploration and extermination, with heroes who go questing, conquering, leveling up, and looting for themselves and their empire. Campaign actions are made on a high-level campaign map. Battles play out on a lower-level map in a tactical turn-based manner, taking into account the terrain and structures of the tile on the campaign map. Both maps use hexagonal tiles. Armies (unit stacks) are composed of up to six units. In a battle, all adjacent armies participate. In some ways, this approach to combat feels like a middle ground between Civilization and Total War.  Much of the design is reminiscent of Master of Magic. Cities and units vary according to the class of the player and the race of the inhabitants. There are six classes (arch druid, dreadnought, rogue, sorceror, theocrat, and warlord) and six races (high elf, human, orc, goblin, dwarf, and draconian). The variety is good but not dizzying, with a solid array of standard unit types and a handful of specialists available in any city that has the requisite buildings. Spellcasting plays a major role on the campaign map and in battles. The spells span a wide spectrum from an assortment that is modest in cost and effect to the immensely powerful and expensive high tier. Each school of magic (among air, earth, fire, water, creation, and destruction) is distinct, with its own characteristic effects and strategies. The interplay between questing, empire building, warfare, and spellcasting is fun, engaging, and balanced.  Compared to other 4X games, there is a diminished emphasis on exploitation. Rather, the exploitation here is ultimately focused on serving the exploration and extermination. You won't find options for cultural, diplomatic, or economic victories here, and the gameplay options are limited likewise. This is not a game of peace. [edit: Interestingly, Triumph has hinted that this is an area that they will expand in upcoming updates.]  The overall fit and finish is very good, although not without room for improvement. The UI is strongly reminiscent of Civilization V—a good choice of inspiration. Some aspects live up to this standard better than others. There is a Tome of Wonders (akin to Civilopedia), but it's a pain to navigate (no back button?! among other problems), and some of its pages neglect important information. Some stats show breakdowns on hover, as they should, but some breakdowns lack desirable detail, while others are simply omitted. I'm curious to see if any of this improves with ongoing updates.  Unlike Civilization and most other games in the 4X genre, a game of Age of Wonders III at normal pace is significantly shorter. Expect a commitment of three to six afternoons instead of three to six full days. Considering the pesky existence of real life, this is a very desirable trait.  If you like 4X and high fantasy, and you'd like a game that combines the two in a form that's easy to swallow, then this is a great choice.

To those who love games like Final Fantasy Tactics, Tactics Ogre, XCOM, etc..., I would highly recommend this game. It takes the core elements of great tactics style RPGs, and throws them inside a slightly simplified empire building game a la Civilization V.  I can acknowledge that the strategic portion of the game lacks some of the depth that can be found in the most hardcore strategy games, but I do not feel this is a flaw. One of the greatest games ever devised, Chess, has only 6 unique pieces, and in its standard style of play, only allows for 1v1 competition. There is a delightfully simple elegance to the units and technologies available in AoWIII (which offer many more choices than Chess). Taken from a purely turn-based strategy game perspective, they would seem shallow compared to the game's peers, but in the context of a deep turn-based tactical RPG (with heroes levelling from 1-30, earning skill points to allocate each level, and spells to research, and gear to equip) it is plenty complex enough.  My favorite thing about this game is how amazingly stable my multiplayer experience has been. My first time launching online multiplayer, it checked my connectivity rating, and told me it was poor due to firewall settings. I clicked a link provided in-game, and in a totally crisp and not buggy fashion, minimized my client and sent me to the company's help page, wherein I was given the neccessary port to forward. I did so, had the game check again, and was good to go. A friend and I have long searched for a good co-operative tactical RPG experience. The best I have yet found was FFT: The Lion War for PSP. It's a shame that a hand-held game system has trumped PC for so long in this niche. XCOM lacks co-op campaign functionality, Eador is horribly buggy and unstable, and the others I've tried are all crumby. In AoWIII, I've found that harmonious combination of enjoyable gameplay and completely (and I mean 8 straight hours of addictive, no crashes or disconnections) stable multiplayer.  Watch some videos of this game and decide if it suits your interests, but as for my opinion, I can give this one an A+.

Empire building - 6 (bog standard, nothing new, very easy to use and the UI is pretty good. Research tree is bland and most of the time you will only have 2 proper options, the rest being superficial or pointless)  Combat - 8 (This game goes from your isometric empire builder to turn based strategy in an instant, with almost no loading time. Units feel varied, combat feels smooth, the UI is better than I expected and is functional and paired with the games research 'tree' you can get some pretty impressive units, like giant rolling warships and cannons)  Graphics - 4 (Easily the worst part of this game is the god awful graphics, don't get me wrong, the Empire map looks great and looks decently made but the character models are some of the worst ive ever seen, hideous.  Gameplay - 8 (I like this game, for a strategy game to work it needs to be complex on several layers, this game is a pleasure to control in every situation, part of this is the great UI, which is both decent looking and practical. Both the Empire map and the Combat are both well put together and work nicely.)  Difficulty - 7 (This one is hard to say, this game is more complex than you'de think, some of the battles ive lost have been to weak armies consisting of units that countered me hard, me obviously not knowing about this)  Content - 8 (This game has Campaigns, random maps which is skirmish mode and scenarios, that's more content than you can shake a stick at. This game also has many races and classes.)  AI - 6 (Stupid but ruthless)  New player experience - 6 (Small but steep learning curve, no indepth tutorial, assumes you know the genre)  In conclusion, I like this game, it provides enough depth for me to keep playing and it has enough variety for me to want to come back to play another match. The strategic level plays very simialr to Civilization games, with considerably less managment involved, with more focus on exploring and fighting than diplomacy. Fighting is the centerpiece of the game with all the myriad units filling thier own niche. The different races have rosters of simialr core units, but each one puts some different twists, either stat or ability wise, such as goblin infantry being the cheapest but having the lowest hitpoints, or orc archers causing bleeding damage and so on. The additon of all sorts of spells across the different classes always makes combat more interesting from chain lightning to cherubs you can usually zap, burn, blast, heal, shield something in the fights. It is a good thing the combat is so interesting though as the strategic level mainly serves as a conduit and context for the turn-based battles, the only way to win is to defeat your enemies, you can form alliances and there is a diplomacy system with dispositions and item and city gifting, but the end goal is usaually either kill everyone, or make a few friends, and kill everyone else. The one sorta exception to that is the independents (minor non-player or cpu factions). These will often be something not found in the normal factions, like giants or faeires or skeletons, and if you can ally with them they will give you a quest, usally involving killing something, and then after 1-3 of these will join your faction, allwoing you to recruit the special units. Of course you could always just kill them and absorbt thier dwellings, effectively accomplishin the same thing. All in all, game is a lot of fun with a lot of replayability, it seems to trade strategic depth on the imperial level for very high quality on the turn-based battles.

LIkes: * Unit-by-unit control on an overworld and battle map. Neutral: * City building and resource management is vital, but lacks much in terms of customization. After you stuff every possible building in a single city, you repeat for other cities. * Research (spells and bonuses) is a nice system (you are unlikely to research everything in a single game), but opaque in terms of what unlocks what.  Dislikes: * Multiplayer generally requires auto-combat to go at a reasonable pace (combat holds a global lock on the game state). * Lower tier units become worthless quickly (except, to some extent, archers). This generally leads to monolithic army compositions later in the game. * Spell disjunction, especially in games with many players, is somewhat annoying; and constantly hampers your ability to do much with spellcasting besides re-casting disjuncted spells.

I would not recommend this game, for singleplayer. There are a few issue's i have that cause me not to enjoy this game. Warning: this is highly subjective, based on personal experience. Therefore i recommend keeping that in mind!  - First the depth. When you start the game and see all the different races and the specialisations you may get the idea that there's alot to discover. However every race play's very alike, there are differences ofcourse but the general concept is the same throughout. (swordsman, archer, pikeman, horseman etc).  The specialisations do bring some variation but the research-tree's attached to them are short. The extra units for each specialisation is a welcome addition, however it's not quite enough.  - Combat/balance. The combat has some meat to it, it's the focus of the game. Some interesting mechanics suchs as attacks of oportunity and hero skills add to the strategic element. But because of the low variety of units it becomes more of the same much too soon.  -Pacing. The big focus in this game is as i said the combat. Sadly around turn 50-60 all units but tier 4 units get less usefull. Wichs results in tier 4 unit spam, it takes away from the already limited choise and variation. And for me that is were most of my games ended, because i did not feel like spamming one unit.  - Diplomacy. Diplomacy is barebone in this game, it's about declaring war or signing a peace treaty. You can interact some more with independant city's, like vasalisation. But when you tend to wage war everyone will like you less, making it harder to have good relations with anyone (as a war decleration effects every other player/independant) it's simply the most viable mechanic by far to just wage war as the only option.   - Strategic placement. This is combat related, you get to choose 6 unit's for each stack. Then you can fight with multiple stacks in one fight to up to (i believe) 48 units. This sounds very nice but there's a big problem that i personally have with it. If you fight with 2 stacks versus one the AI tends to advance towards one of them. That leaves the other to catch up since the distance between allied stacks is relatively large.  Because of that the reason to fight with multiple stacks becomes less important, your main stack is gonna do most of the work (hopefully, the AI might attack the other stack).  Or the AI splits it's army destroying it's chances on it's own.  In encounters (versus independants roaming or placed around the map) the battlefield is so small that ranged units can reach your army in the first turn. And they get to go first because you attacked. So they get a free attack in.... does not seem very strategic.  - City defense. This seems to be done by placing units within the city, wich cost upkeep. The AI will ninja your city, it even intends to do so. The only way is to use units wich should have bin fighting in your army, there should be a building for it, but none to find.  -Graphics. This is done fairly well, the game does look beautifull and the animation quality is high. It also runs very well and support for the game is good, the devs are very active and helpful!  All in all i expected something along the lines of Warlock or HoMM. But this is a different creature entirely. That said the issue's i have may not be a problem for others, as many people do like this game. And for good reason, i did like aspects of it very much. Sadly the points mentioned made it not so enjoyable for me personally.  I would not recommend unless none of the above is an issue, if you do get it i'd recommend to wait for a sale (it happends frequently)!
